awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Robust Processing of Data Streams in Real Time
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the problem of scheduling the processing of collections of streams of medical sensor data, with a goal of providing high-confidence per-packet service guarantees that are robust to variability in the stream generation and concomitant changes in the loads at the distributed set of resources where streams are processed.  Given the NP-Hard complexity of optimal stream scheduling and the need to handle streams that are stochastic in nature, the service guarantees are probabilistic.  The approach makes use of statistical and machine learning techniques, harnessing a mix of application-independent and application-dependent features to adaptively orchestrate stream processing over a collection of resources with dynamic utilization profiles while retaining the ability to prioritize processing under heavy load, for multiple concurrent applications. Data from clinical and assisted living settings are used to evaluate the efficacy of solutions.

Health care and homeland security can benefit from this research, as well as experimental science.  Skyrocketing healthcare costs have coincided with the proliferation of electronic monitoring devices in medical and assisted living environments, which generate data streams of patient data.  Timely monitoring and analysis of these streams can detect emergencies early and improve patient outcomes, but failure can be fatal. Improvements in the efficiency and robustness of automated medical data stream processing translate to lower costs and improved outcomes. There are analogous opportunities in homeland security, where chemical and biological sensor data must be processed in real-time for threat evaluation. Open-source software produced as part of this research, which can be configured over an arbitrary number of machines to process a large number of streams in a variety of settings, lowers entry barriers for scientists who need to process observational data in their applications.  The project will also provide educational opportunities for students, and middle school outreach activities targeted at improving assimilation of mathematical concepts among Native American students.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Research Innovations
This effort advanced the science of data stream processing. Data streams occur naturally in settings such as continuous sensing environments, monitoring, Internet of Things (IoT), and edge computing. This effort produced (1) a state-of-the-art algorithm for online scheduling of streams that is robust to uncertainty in data generation patterns, resource utilization, and resource slowdowns, and (2) a holistic methodology that addresses the CPU, memory, network, and kernel issues involved in stream processing. These innovations are applicable to a broad class of stream processing applications that arise in healthcare, monitoring (chemical, biological, and ecological), and other IoT-enabled sensing domains. The project also generated over 30 peer-reviewed publications in top computer science journals and conferences, 4 Ph.D. dissertations, and 7 masters theses.

Our methodology focuses on reducing interference between stream processing computations in the presence of variability in processing workloads and system conditions. This is achieved through a series of proactive, continuous, and incremental scheduling decisions where computations are migrated to machines with less interference. These migrations help reduce resource utilization imbalances within the cluster while alleviating performance hotspots, both of which improve performance.

To inform online scheduling of computations, we introduced the notion of an interference score. The interference score is a normalized score that quantifies the expected interference for a stream computation when placed on a particular machine. The methodology includes mechanisms to counteract oscillations, cascading migrations, and frequent inefficient migrations.

The effort resulted in several innovations to ensure high-throughput processing while ensuring low latencies. Our methodology maximizes bandwidth utilization in the presence of small messages via the use of buffering and dynamic compactions of packets based on payload entropy. Our use of thread pools and batched processing reduces context switches and improves effective CPU utilizations. We also alleviate memory pressure that can lead to swapping, page faults, and thrashing through efficient reuse of objects. We addressed issues relating to processing at the edges, cloud bursting to alleviate capacity constraints, and informing placement and migration decisions of VMs in public and private clouds.



Education and Outreach
This effort developed a residential, week-long educational camp-Math in Action in Computer Science (MACS). The MACS camp was held annually for 5 years starting in 2013. The goal of the camp was to use hands-on training to show middle school students how the math concepts they were learning in school were applied to real-world problems in computer science and elsewhere. To maximize its impact, the camp targeted Native American middle school students ? an at-risk demographic with a high dropout rate between middle and high school.

Each year students attended the weeklong, summer, residential camp and immersed themselves in learning functions, probability, distance measures, matrices, measures of central tendency, and plenty of programming including basics, use of operators, control flow, and data structures. To embed concepts, MACS instructors leveraged experiential learning techniques such as games, worksheets, white board sessions, and programming. The students also created websites and did reflective writing assignments to further solidify their understanding.

MACS camp benefited more than just the middle school students. Two math teachers from Cortez Middle School also attended the camp and had the opportunity to learn new and different perspectives on the subject matter and techniques in math pedagogy. There was a 2:1 student to instructor ratio allowing for intensive help, explanation, and interaction.

Over its 5-year duration, MACS participants and supporters included: 

  • 57 Cortez Middle School students
  • 4 Cortez math teachers
  • 14 CSU student instructors
  • 2 CSU student mentors
  • 17 guest speakers
  • 15 CSU units and external organizations including the American Indian College Fund. 

 

 

Impact on Graduate Research and Education
This project resulted in 4 Ph.D. dissertations, and three of the students -- Kathleen Ericson, Wesley Lloyd, and Matthew Malensek -- are currently Assistant Professors of Computer Science. Matthew's dissertation was honored with the IEEE TCSC Outstanding Ph.D. Dissertation Award in 2018.  The project also produced 7 masters theses -- one of these students, Thilina Buddhika, is expected to complete his Ph.D. next year.

 

 

Impact on Undergraduate Research and Education
Eleven undergraduate students participated in this research as part of the NSF REU program. Five are female, and five completed (or are in the process of completing) their graduate degrees. 

 

 

Data Management
All software produced as part of this effort is open source and is available at http://granules.cs.colostate.edu. All course materials developed as part of the middle school outreach are freely available at http://macs.cs.colostate.edu. This includes programs, presentations, and lesson plans for the modules comprising the educational outreach. Lecture materials from the undergraduate course on distributed systems are freely available at: http://www.cs.colostate.edu/~cs455/

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2019
Modified by: Shrideep B Pallickara
